hedline.hl1: Compressed Data; Trial Involving DVD Software And Copyrights Set to Begin

abstract.p: Lawsuit brought by eight leading Hollywood movie studios against Eric Corley, editor and publisher of 2600: The Hacker Quarterly, is set to get under way in Manhattan; studios charge Corley violated Digital Millennium Copyright Act of 1998 by posting on his Web site the underground computer program DeCSS, which allows users to bypass security system of DVD movie disks, thus paving the way to unauthorized viewing, copying and online transmission of movies; Corley's lawyers argue that DeCSS merely allows fans of Linux operating system to watch, on their computers, DVD movies they already own (M)

block.p: An important Internet case -- one that pits Hollywood's right to control access to its digital wares against consumers' rights to fair use of copyrighted material -- is scheduled to get under way in United States District Court in Manhattan today.

The case involves an underground computer program, DeCSS, which, Hollywood executives say, allows users to bypass the security system of DVD movie disks, thus paving the way to unauthorized viewing, copying and online transmission of movies.

An important Internet case -- one that pits Hollywood's right to control access to its digital wares against consumers' rights to fair use of copyrighted material -- is scheduled to get under way in United States District Court in Manhattan today.

The case involves an underground computer program, DeCSS, which, Hollywood executives say, allows users to bypass the security system of DVD movie disks, thus paving the way to unauthorized viewing, copying and online transmission of movies.

The plaintiffs are eight leading Hollywood movie studios. They are suing Eric Corley, editor and publisher of a print and Web publication, 2600: The Hacker Quarterly, for posting the DeCSS software on his Web site and linking to other Web sites that post it.

The studios say that Mr. Corley's distribution of the software violates a federal law, the Digital Millennium Copyright Act of 1998. A section of that law makes it illegal for anyone to offer to the public a device intended to circumvent a technological barrier to a copyright-protected work.

Lawyers for Mr. Corley, who also uses the name Emmanuel Goldstein, have argued that DeCSS is merely a way to help fans of the Linux operating system watch, on their computers, DVD movies they already own.

The plaintiffs want the court to ban Mr. Corley from posting, linking to or otherwise ''trafficking'' in the DeCSS code. Two other defendants have settled with the movie studios, agreeing not to post the software.

The studios filed their suit in January, and so far the defense, led by Martin Garbus, has had a difficult time. Early on, Judge Lewis A. Kaplan sided with the movie studios and granted a preliminary injunction barring Mr. Corley from posting the code.
Last month, Judge Kaplan called the issues in the trial ''narrow and well-defined.''

Mr. Garbus conceded that it might be difficult for him to prevail at trial. Already, he said, he is mentally preparing for an appeal. If Judge Kaplan continues to take a narrow view of the issues in the case, then ''it's going to be a three-minute trial,'' Mr. Garbus said.
